author: By Dan Levin and Michael Levenson
title: 3 Killed, Including Gunman, in Shooting at Louisiana Gun Store
description: Two other people were injured and in stable condition after the shooting at the Jefferson Gun Outlet in Metairie, La., the police said.
content: METAIRIE, La. — A gunman opened fire at a combination gun store and indoor firing range near New Orleans on Saturday, killing two people before others returned fire, killing him, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Dobbins and Will Wright
title: A Texas apartment building burned while firefighters scrambled for water.
description: SAN ANTONIO — A 32-unit apartment complex near San Antonio burned down on Thursday night into Friday morning as fire hydrants ran dry after a winter storm that disrupted the water supply for millions of Texans.
content: SAN ANTONIO — A 32-unit apartment complex near San Antonio burned down on Thursday night into Friday morning as fire hydrants ran dry after a winter storm that disrupted the water supply for millions of Texans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Filipovic
title: The Life and Death of a Woman-Hater
description: Rush Limbaugh made the G.O.P. the party of misogyny.
content: When the conservative talk radio host Rush Limbaugh died on Wednesday of complications from cancer, he ended a decades-long career as one of the most malignant and sadistic figures on the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: A second Google A.I. researcher says the company fired her.
description: Two months after the jarring departure of a well-known artificial intelligence researcher at Google, a second A.I. researcher at the company said she was fired after criticizing the way it has treated employees who were working on ways to address bias and toxicity in its artificial intelligence systems.
content: Two months after the jarring departure of a well-known artificial intelligence researcher at Google, a second A.I. researcher at the company said she was fired after criticizing the way it has treated employees who were working on ways to address bias and toxicity in its artificial intelligence systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Where Biden’s Virus Plan Stands
description: The president visits a vaccine plant as he faces thorny questions on fulfilling his promises.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chocolate on the Mind
description: From desserts for two to chickpea stew, here are the recipes our readers were craving this week.
content: From puddings to cakes, our readers had chocolate on the mind this week. And just because Valentine’s Day is in the rearview mirror doesn’t mean Yossi Arefi’s two-serving chocolate pudding with raspberry cream (above) or her lava cake for two can’t be on the menu this weekend. You’ll find those recipes, and more savory options to have alongside them, in our collection of the 10 most popular recipes on NYT Cooking right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Let’s Talk Policy
description: What does the road to recovery look like?
content: Top policymakers and business leaders will assemble virtually next week for the DealBook DC Policy Project, to discuss the future of politics, the economy, markets and more. Register here to join us, from anywhere in the world, free of charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany, Once a Model, Is Swamped Like Everyone Else by Pandemic’s Second Wave
description: After winning widespread recognition for its handling of the coronavirus last year, Germany now finds itself struggling with its sluggish vaccine rollout and a frustrated population.
content: ROSTOCK, Germany — It was barely noon, but Steffen Bockhahn’s phone had not stopped ringing with people wanting to know if they qualified for a vaccination, and if not now, when?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Air Force Training Jet Crashes in Alabama, Killing 2
description: The T-38 was assigned to the 14th Flying Training Wing at Columbus Air Force Base in Mississippi and went down in a wooded area near the Montgomery Regional Airport, officials said.
content: An Air Force training plane flying from Columbus, Miss., to Tallahassee, Fla., crashed in a wooded area near the Montgomery Regional Airport in Alabama on Friday evening, killing the two people aboard, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Mixed Doubles, Often Neglected, Crowns Resilient Champions
description: After a 14-day quarantine in their hotel rooms, Rajeev Ram and Barbora Krejcikova rolled through the draw and claimed victory at the Australian Open.
content: After they arrived in Melbourne, Rajeev Ram and Barbora Krejcikova received notice that passengers on their respective charter flights had tested positive for the coronavirus. The two were among the 72 players then forced to enter a 14-day “hard quarantine” in their hotel rooms, denied the opportunities to go outside and practice that were afforded other players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Meridith Kohut
title: Venezuelan Women Lose Access to Contraception, and Control of Their Lives
description: Affordable birth control has disappeared, pushing many women into unplanned pregnancies at a time when they can barely feed the children they already have.
content: SAN DIEGO DE LOS ALTOS, Venezuela — The moment Johanna Guzmán, 25, discovered she was going to have her sixth child she began to sob, crushed by the idea of bringing another life into a nation in such decay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Montana and the Dakotas were hot spots. Until they weren’t.
description: The spike in these states was as brief as it was powerful. Today, their rates of new cases are back roughly to where they were last summer or early fall.
content: Not three months ago, the coronavirus had so ravaged South Dakota that its packed hospitals were flying patients to other states for treatment. An analysis of data collected by Johns Hopkins University had shown that the mortality rates from Covid-19 in North and South Dakota were the world’s highest. In one Montana county, the rate of hospitalization for the virus was 20 times the national average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: Who Will Be the Next F.D.A. Chief?
description: Two leading contenders generate wider debate about the leadership needed to restore morale and scientific integrity to an agency battered by the politicized Trump administration.
content: One month into his presidency, President Biden still has not named a candidate to head the Food and Drug Administration, a critical position at a time when new vaccines and coronavirus treatments are under the agency’s review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Selinger
title: Who Is Still Buying VHS Tapes?
description: Despite the rise of streaming, there is still a vast library of moving images that are categorically unavailable anywhere else. Also a big nostalgia factor.
content: The last VCR, according to Dave Rodriguez, 33, a digital repository librarian at Florida State University in Tallahassee, Fla., was produced in 2016, by the Funai Electric in Osaka, Japan. But the VHS tape itself may be immortal. Today, a robust marketplace exists, both virtually and in real life, for this ephemera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Is Said to Be Examining Stone’s Possible Ties to Capitol Rioters
description: A full criminal investigation is far from certain, a person familiar with the inquiry said.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is examining communications between right-wing extremists who breached the Capitol and Roger J. Stone Jr., a close associate of former President Donald J. Trump, to determine whether Mr. Stone played any role in the extremists’ plans to disrupt the certification of President Biden’s electoral victory, a person familiar with the matter said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Ex-Artistic Director of Greece’s National Theater Held After Rape Arrest Warrant
description: The case of Dimitris Lignadis is the most high-profile among the numerous directors and actors to have been named in a torrent of accusations that have rocked the Greek arts world.
content: ATHENS — The Greek police on Saturday evening arrested the former artistic director of the country’s prestigious National Theater, who has been the target of accusations of sexual abuse and harassment that have buffeted the Greek arts world over the past weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: This week in Covid-19 news: Biden attempts to reassure, Cuba makes vaccine progress and governors are under fire.
description: In his first trips as president, President Biden traveled to Wisconsin and Michigan to promote his vaccination rollout plan and the $1.9 trillion relief bill he hopes can restore the American economy.
content: In his first trips as president, President Biden traveled to Wisconsin and Michigan to promote his vaccination rollout plan and the $1.9 trillion relief bill he hopes can restore the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Tomb of Joshua, Revered Prophet, Beckons Believers in Baghdad
description: No one knows for certain if Joshua, the Old Testament prophet, actually lived or where he might be buried. But for over 1,000 years, the sick and faithful have visited a Baghdad tomb said to be his.
content: BAGHDAD — Down the road from the railway yard where plastic trash piles up against rusting freight cars, the angels arrive every evening to stand watch over the tomb of Joshua. A servant of the shrine, Um Junayd, said she sees them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Finding Flowers, and Solace, in the Cracks and Grit of an Urban Jungle
description: In densely packed Tokyo, flora is abundant in unassuming places. Hunting for it, as I learned, can lighten life’s loads.
content: Not long after we moved to Japan, I came to appreciate the public obsession with flowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Rush Limbaugh and the Petrification of Conservatism
description: An extraordinary career for the man, a long defeat for his ideology.
content: Rush Limbaugh, dead this week at 70, was probably the most influential figure among the men who defined conservatism after Ronald Reagan. He was the presiding genius of a media revolution that still reverberates today — on your favorite podcast as much as the talk radio dial. And his political legacy feels like the result of an unfortunate encounter between a 1980s young Republican and a tempting monkey’s paw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Australian Open 2021: In Defeat, Jennifer Brady Proves She Belongs
description: Appearing in her first Grand Slam final, the 25-year-old American started slow against Naomi Osaka, but rallied to go down fighting.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — She was playing with house money, a No. 22 seed who spent 15 days confined to a hotel room last month, a former U.C.L.A. Bruin who went to college because she did not have the head for professional tennis at 18 years old and was in need of a backup plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Schedules Address Before CPAC Next Sunday
description: The former president will make his first lengthy remarks since leaving office before the annual conference of conservatives Feb. 28.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will speak at the conservative event known as CPAC on Feb. 28, his first public appearance and lengthy address since he left the White House for a final time last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Tale of the Untamable Shrew
description: Republicans are still trying to muzzle a smack-talking Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — Is Shakespeare a misogynist?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: N.C.A.A. Basketball Tournaments Will Welcome Fans After All
description: Some epidemiologists say it’s a bad idea, because the games will attract people from all over the country to Indianapolis and San Antonio, the cities that will host every game of the men’s and women’s tournaments.
content: The N.C.A.A. announced on Friday that it would welcome fans — tens of thousands of them — to Indianapolis and San Antonio, where the entire men’s and women’s basketball tournaments are to be held this season, in a move that will generate millions in ticket revenue but risk further spread of the coronavirus to and from far-flung regions of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Interest Surges in Top Colleges, While Struggling Ones Scrape for Applicants
description: Waiving standardized test requirements during the pandemic brought more hopefuls to the Ivy League and large state schools, while less-selective colleges face an alarming drop.
content: Prestigious universities like Cornell never have a hard time attracting students. But this year, the admissions office in Ithaca, N.Y., is swimming in 17,000 more applications than it has ever received before, driven mostly by the school’s decision not to require standardized test scores during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A Musical Life With Echoes That Will Last
description: The lessons that the piano teacher Cornelia Vertenstein taught her students also resounded with many others, including me.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russian Court Clears Way to Send Navalny to a Penal Colony
description: The fate of opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny remains unclear, however. He could be held in a high-security prison in Moscow for other pending legal matters.
content: MOSCOW — A Russian court cleared the way on Saturday for the possible transfer of the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny to the country’s penal colony system, the latest step by the authorities to silence the man who has become the country’s most vocal critic of President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: United Flight Sheds Debris Over Colorado After Engine Failure
description: The airplane, which had 241 people on board, scattered debris across several neighborhoods outside Boulder, Colo., before landing safely in Denver, officials said.
content: A United Airlines flight with 241 people on board experienced engine failure over a suburb of Boulder, Colo., on Saturday afternoon, shedding debris across three neighborhoods before landing safely in Denver, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Must We Dance on Rush Limbaugh’s Grave?
description: Speaking ill of the dead needn’t mean cackling over their demise.
content: “Not proud of this,” a friend wrote to me in a text message mere minutes after the news broke on Wednesday, “but feeling really good about Rush Limbaugh dying.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Azi Paybarah
title: Texas Winter Storm: What to Know
description: Power outages and no running water have left Texas and other parts of the South still feeling the effects of a deep freeze that swept the region earlier this week.
content: Texans were tossed from one crisis to another this week as frigid temperatures and winter weather battered the state and the surrounding region, leaving many people in dire situations and grasping for the most basic of needs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Naomi Osaka Beats Jennifer Brady at Australian Open for Her 4th Grand Slam Title
description: Osaka, 23, has won every Grand Slam final she has reached.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The most uncomfortable moment for Naomi Osaka on Saturday night was not when she faced a key break point in the first set of her Australian Open women’s singles final against Jennifer Brady. Nor was it when she was serving for the match in the second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Tom Ford on Wearing the Same Ripped Jeans and Allowing Himself to ‘Be Unproductive’
description: As New York Fashion Week ends, the designer and film director explains why his show was postponed and how he has been affected by the pandemic.
content: Until last week, Tom Ford — designer, film director and chairman of the Council of Fashion Designers of America — had never done an Instagram Live interview. In fact, he said, he exists on Instagram under a secret name, known only to close friends, to protect his privacy and see what people are doing. (His corporate account is run by an employee.) But he agreed to talk to The New York Times for a special fashion week series, speaking from his empty atelier in Los Angeles. This interview has been edited and condensed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Lessons of the Texas Power Disaster
description: The entire nation’s energy delivery system needs an overhaul.
content: There is a great deal of nonsense being written and spoken about this week’s power failures in Texas, which left a number of people dead and millions without power or potable water, sometimes for days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Merrick Garland Faces Resurgent Peril After Years Fighting Extremism
description: The fallout from the Capitol attack and the shadow of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing are likely to take center stage at the confirmation hearings for President Biden’s pick for attorney general.
content: WASHINGTON — Judge Merrick B. Garland always made a point of wearing a coat and tie when he surveyed the wreckage at the site of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing, the worst domestic terrorist attack in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger and Roger Cohen
title: Biden Tells Allies ‘America Is Back,’ but Macron and Merkel Push Back
description: All three leaders seemed to recognize, though, that their first virtual encounter was a moment to celebrate the end of the “America First” era.
content: President Biden used his first public encounter with America’s European allies to describe a new struggle between the West and the forces of autocracy, declaring that “America is back” while acknowledging that the past four years had taken a toll on its power and influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Dutch Officials Urge New Look at Claim on Painting by Jewish Heirs
description: The heirs have argued that the work by Wassily Kandinsky was sold under duress by its Jewish owners after the Nazi invasion of the Netherlands.
content: The mayor of Amsterdam has decided it is time to revisit the question of whether the city’s Stedelijk Museum should hold onto a 1909 painting by Wassily Kandinsky that had been part of a Jewish collection before it was obtained by the museum during World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ioan Grillo
title: Slow the Iron River of Guns to Mexico
description: The Biden administration has an opportunity to stem illegal gun trafficking to Mexico and beyond.
content: MEXICO CITY — In 2008, the U.S. gun maker Colt, based in Hartford, Conn., produced a special edition .38 Super pistol that was engraved by a partner company with an image of the Mexican revolutionary Emiliano Zapata. In 2017, an assassin used the weapon to shoot dead a prolific Mexican investigative journalist, Miroslava Breach, as she drove her son to school in the city of Chihuahua. It was a cruel irony: An American gun embellished with an image of a Mexican freedom fighter was used to silence Mexico’s freedom of speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: The Boredom Economy
description: The pandemic is terrible. It can also be tedious. And that tedium is shaping what people buy and how productive they are.
content: Mark Hawkins is an expert on being bored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Is the Group Chat Sacred?
description: Heidi Cruz learned the hard way that text chains can be leaked.
content: My moms message group has long been a solace to me, especially in this pandemic year. It is a place to vent and plan and strategize, and I have definitely said many things I would not want to be blasted out into public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: Rush Limbaugh as Seen by Four Writers
description: Examining how the controversial commentator changed America.
content: Times Opinion doesn’t often publish four pieces reflecting on the death of one person, but few Americans have left as big a mark on politics, media and culture as Rush Limbaugh did over the past three decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sci-Fi Portals
description: Ali Gascoigne draws us in with a galactic Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ali Gascoigne is one of our constructors who also “sets” cryptic crosswords, often under the pseudonyms Gila and Jalna. Cryptic puzzles use a blizzard of puns and tricks to twist every entry, and you’ll find breezy examples of this throughout the grid today, although many of them will be expanded to be more straightforward for our standard endeavor. Still makes for a good challenge, with a wry flair to a lot of it. As is my habit lately, I found my solve split vertically down the middle — I struggled mightily with the west side and cruised through the east side — but I’m unsure whether there was really a difference in difficulty, or if I just needed to warm up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
title: Seeking Fresh Start With Iraq, Biden Avoids Setting Red Lines With Iran
description: The administration’s measured response to a rocket attack in Erbil sharply contrasts with a Trump-era campaign against Iran that, more often than not, caught Iraq in the crossfire.
content: WASHINGTON — After a rocket attack on the American Embassy in Baghdad late last year, the Trump administration renewed its threats of withdrawing diplomats from Iraq. A military retaliation against Iran was discussed, and the White House warned of a drastic response “if one American is killed.” None was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Where Will Rush Limbaugh’s 15 Million Listeners Go Now?
description: No one will have a megaphone like his again. But podcasters, “26-year-old conservatives on Instagram” and Sean Hannity all fill the void.
content: So who now takes the place of Rush Limbaugh as the media ringmaster of the right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Cruz and Cuomo Face Scandal. Trump Can’t Save Them.
description: Without Donald Trump dominating the political conversation, politicians’ audacious behavior isn’t so quickly subsumed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Myanmar Security Forces Open Fire on Protesters, Killing 2
description: At least 40 people protesting the military’s ouster of civilian leaders were wounded in the city of Mandalay, volunteer medics said.
content: Security forces in Myanmar opened fire on protesters in the city of Mandalay on Saturday, killing two people and wounding dozens, according to witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Collision at Anfield Does Little to Slow Liverpool’s Fall
description: Everton’s victory, a cause for deserved celebration, reveals a broken Liverpool team holding tight to a system that has stopped working.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — It is every week, now, that Liverpool seems to lose another little piece of itself. An unbeaten home record that stretched back more than three years disappeared in January, spirited away by Burnley. The sense of Anfield as a fortress collapsed soon after, stormed in short order by Brighton and then by Manchester City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Your Kids Aren’t Too Old for Picture Books, and Neither Are You
description: These are the real wizards of the literary world.
content: “My kid has outgrown picture books.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Halpern
title: Desperate for Distraction, We Chose Dragons
description: A game of fantasy offers a way out of isolation.
content: We had to get out of the house. My wife and two sons, ages 11 and 14, were dying for a bit of adventure, and there are only so many shows on Animal Planet that you can watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Dianna Ortiz, American Nun Tortured in Guatemala, Dies at 62
description: She became a champion of survivors of torture and helped compel the release of documents showing U.S. complicity in decades of human rights abuses in Guatemala.
content: Dianna Ortiz, an American Roman Catholic nun whose rape and torture in Guatemala in 1989 helped lead to the release of documents showing American involvement in human rights abuses in that country, died on Friday in hospice care in Washington. She was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Democrats Beat Trump in 2020. Now They’re Asking: What Went Wrong?
description: Disappointed by down-ballot losses, Democratic interest groups are joining forces to conduct an autopsy of the election results. Republicans do not yet seem willing to reckon with the G.O.P.’s major defeats.
content: Democrats emerged from the 2020 election with full control of the federal government and a pile of lingering questions. In private, party leaders and strategists have been wrestling with a quandary: Why was President Biden’s convincing victory over Donald J. Trump not accompanied by broad Democratic gains down ballot?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: What Are Sperm Telling Us?
description: Scientists are concerned by falling sperm counts and declining egg quality. Endocrine-disrupting chemicals may be the problem.
content: Something alarming is happening between our legs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: Octopuses Have a Secret Sense to Keep Their 8 Arms Out of Trouble
description: Even when an octopus can’t see light with its eyes, its arms seem to know it is there.
content: Though it is well-known for its many arms, the octopus does not seem to know where those eight appendages are most of the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle, Brad Plumer and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Texas Blackouts Point to Coast-to-Coast Crises Waiting to Happen
description: Continent-spanning storms triggered blackouts in Oklahoma and Mississippi, halted one-third of U.S. oil production and disrupted vaccinations in 20 states.
content: Even as Texas struggled to restore electricity and water over the past week, signs of the risks posed by increasingly extreme weather to America’s aging infrastructure were cropping up across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon dress us up in a botanical, boozy puzzle.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — Today we have a really appealing puzzle, one that I would clip and save for those people who say cryptics are too obscure, abstruse and impossible for them. This grid offers up the usual assortment of anagrams, charades, hidden words and so on — anyone who’s new to these categories can use a guide like this one — but they’re pretty much all in pure form, not muddled together. I don’t see a single clue or entry that doesn’t “work” beautifully, and yet the solve is far from easy — it took two sessions for me, with some cogitation breaks in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: In Canada, Did a Comedian’s Joke Go Too Far?
description: A Supreme Court case focused on a comedy routine mocking a disabled teenager could help shape the limits of free speech — and humor — in Canada.
content: MONTREAL — About a decade ago, the comedian Mike Ward, of Quebec, mocked the voice of a well-known disabled teenage singer in a standup routine, roasting him for being off-key, making fun of his hearing aid and calling him “ugly.” But he said he had defended the boy to others because he would soon die. When the teen didn’t die of his illness, the comedian joked, he tried to drown him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shapiro
title: The House That Rush Built
description: How Rush Limbaugh broke the liberal hegemony in broadcast media.
content: On Wednesday, after a yearlong battle with lung cancer, Rush Limbaugh died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Australian Open 2021: Novak Djokovic and Daniil Medvedev Meet for the Title
description: Djokovic, aiming for his ninth title in the tournament, should face a strong challenge from Medvedev.
content: How to watch: The match is at 3:30 a.m. Eastern time on Sunday on ESPN, ESPN Deportes and ESPN+. There will be encore showings at 8 a.m. and 11 p.m. on ESPN2.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 21, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 21, 2021.
content: An article on Page 6 about the conceptual artist Lorraine O’Grady misstates the date of Manet’s painting, “Olympia.” While first displayed in Paris in 1865, it was painted in 1863. The article also described incorrectly the subject of the painting as aristocratic. While the model herself was a Parisian artist, the character she portrays is a courtesan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Brutal Cold Kills Texans in Beds, Yards and Cars
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 20, 2021.
content: “Texas is not meant to handle freezing temperatures. It’s not something that happens out here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Entire School Board Resigns After Members Are Caught Mocking Parents on Livestream
description: Unaware their conversation was public, district trustees in Oakley, Calif., suggested that parents eager for schools to reopen merely wanted “their babysitters back.”
content: “Uh-oh.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Karaoke Bars
description: Matthew Stock hits a high note in his Sunday debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Among the many things that people might miss when they don’t read this column: Today is Feb. 21, 2021, and you have before you a 21x21 grid. A nice bit of symmetry that I wouldn’t have noticed myself were it not for our constructor, Matthew Stock, who teaches algebra — makes sense! — in St. Louis. This is Mr. Stock’s third Times puzzle, as well as his third Times puzzle this year, which is pretty unusual and puts a lot of pressure on him to maintain a frenetic pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Why Canada’s Vaccine Rollout Slowed Down
description: The government did not promise mass inoculations during the first few months, but reductions and suspensions of shipments have created vaccine anxiety.
content: The large batches of Pfizer vaccines that landed in Canada this week from a plant in Belgium may represent a turning point in the country’s vaccination roll out, even as winter storms delayed the shipments’ arrival.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Secrets
description: Why we tell them, and what happens after we do.
content: Why we tell them, and what happens after we do.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Brief Australian Open Recap: Osaka Beats Brady
description: Naomi Osaka won her fourth Grand Slam singles championship on Saturday by defeating Jennifer Brady 6-4, 6-3 at the Australian Open. Here’s how she did it.
content: Naomi Osaka won her fourth Grand Slam singles championship on Saturday by defeating Jennifer Brady 6-4, 6-3 at the Australian Open. Here’s how she did it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Conlen and Charlie Smart
title: When Could the United States Reach Herd Immunity? It’s Complicated.
description: See how vaccines, distancing measures and the rise of coronavirus variants affect projections for herd immunity and when we might reach it.
content: See how vaccines, distancing measures and the rise of coronavirus variants affect projections for herd immunity and when we might reach it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: It’s Been a Busy Month on Mars
description: When NASA’s Perseverance rover landed on the red planet on Thursday, it was the end of a bustling cycle of activity.
content: When NASA’s Perseverance rover landed on the red planet on Thursday, it was the end of a bustling cycle of activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: U.S. Rejoins Paris Climate Agreement
description: President Biden told leaders of the Group of 7 nations that climate change was a priority for his administration as the United States formally rejoined the Paris climate agreement on Friday.
content: President Biden told leaders of the Group of 7 nations that climate change was a priority for his administration as the United States formally rejoined the Paris climate agreement on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Biden Challenges Detractors of His Coronavirus Relief Bill
description: President Biden on Friday called on Republicans who have complained that his $1.9 trillion economic relief package is too large to name which specific provisions they would prefer to cut from the bill.
content: President Biden on Friday called on Republicans who have complained that his $1.9 trillion economic relief package is too large to name which specific provisions they would prefer to cut from the bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Myanmar Security Forces Crack Down on Protesters
description: Security forces on Saturday opened fire on protesters in Mandalay, Myanmar, according to witnesses, killing two people and wounding dozens. Demonstrators have been rallying for weeks against the Feb. 1 military coup.
content: Security forces on Saturday opened fire on protesters in Mandalay, Myanmar, according to witnesses, killing two people and wounding dozens. Demonstrators have been rallying for weeks against the Feb. 1 military coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Boris Johnson Calls for G7 Cooperation on Global Threats
description: Boris Johnson, the British prime minister, hosted a virtual meeting with leaders of the Group of 7 nations on Friday and outlined the need for a multilateral approach to global vaccinations and the fight against climate change.
content: Boris Johnson, the British prime minister, hosted a virtual meeting with leaders of the Group of 7 nations on Friday and outlined the need for a multilateral approach to global vaccinations and the fight against climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: California Will Reserve Vaccine Doses for Teachers and School Staff
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Friday that, starting on March 1, California will set aside 10 percent of the state’s first doses of Covid-19 vaccine for educators and school employees.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Friday that, starting on March 1, California will set aside 10 percent of the state’s first doses of Covid-19 vaccine for educators and school employees.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Using Smartphone Data to ID Members of the Capitol Mob
description: Readers discuss the privacy issues raised. One argues, “Americans’ obsession with privacy has gone off the rails.”

title: Corrections: Feb. 20, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 20, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about the successful landing of the new robotic rover Perseverance on Mars misstated the year the Spirit and Opportunity rovers landed on Mars. It was 2004, not 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Capitol: ‘Don’t Fence Me In’?
description: Is a permanent fence an affront to Frederick Law Olmsted’s design and “the ideals of democracy that the Capitol grounds represent”? Or must the government “take appropriate measures to thwart attacks”?
